bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 19, 1941

div1.p: Hench insists that in a historical painting, like the yellow fever painting, all figures should be identified. He suggests Carter and Ames be included.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 19, 1941
div1.opener:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
August 19, 1941
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
DR. CHARLES H. SLOCUMB
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I will enclose for your interest a partial list of the data that I found
in Washington and I hope to trace more of it down the next time I come. Perhaps
I mentioned to you that I am invited to speak before the American Academy of
Orthopedic Surgeons in Washington in January and I hope to spend two or three
extra days in Washington at that time. I also enclose a copy of Bullard's story
which I finally got around to write up. I thought you might be interested in it
even though you may not have any comments or corrections to make. However, do
you happen to know what the General Wood Laboratory was, mentioned on page 4?
I am sending Mr. Bullard a copy for his final correction and approval.

I shall be delighted to do whatever I can in defending the Roll of Honor
and I can assure you that I will take this obligation most seriously. I appre-
ciate greatly the confidence you express in me to suggest this.

I am anxious to have from you, at your earliest convenience, your consid-
eration of the following matter. When the yellow fever painting was first pro-
posed, you will remember that it was my thought to avoid controversy by merely
including the five top men--Finlay and the four members of the Commission. Others
had definite ideas, in particular, General Truby, who wished to see if possible
the entire group portrayed. Still others nominated Carter, General Wood and others
for the portrait. Mr. Cornwell apparently compromised. He did not originally
want a large group as he said it would be too stiff but finally he did include
in a tentative drawing which he sent me, thirteen figures. In my correspondence
with him and when I visited his studio in New York at his request, on my way home
from Cuba, I tried to find out just whom all these figures were supposed to repre-
sent. The figures of Finlay, Agramonte, Carroll, Reed and Lazear were obvious;
also those of Moran and Kissinger. But they didn't really have any definite idea
who the others were. Apparently they were just put in to lend action and balance
to the painting. The mustachioed figure next to Moran on Moran's right was to be
Jernegan. The reason Jernegan was selected was because he had a picturesque face
as seen in the photograph of the hospital detachment on the stairs. I heartily
agreed that Jernegan should be included because he submitted to practically every-
thing given. I made the suggestion that the figure of one of the Cuban volunteers
be inserted in an inconspicuous place and this was done in the later versions.
So far as I know, neither Mr. Kellogg nor Mr. Cornwell had definitely identified
the two figures seated with Carroll at the table, the two men on the porch railing
or the additional soldier volunteer in the background on the right. Please do not
misunderstand me. I do not wish to take undue credit and quite possibly others
made the suggestion also but I insisted that in such a historical portrait every
person should be identified and have a right to be there. Therefore, I suggested
that both you (General Kean) and General Truby be included, that General Wood be
portrayed and that Dr. Cooke at least be included. In pursuance of this suggestion
the seated figure on the left became you (General Kean) and I showed Mr. Cornwell
a picture of you which you had so kindly given me. I thought it most appropriate
General Kean - 2 - August 19, 1941
that General Wood should be the seated figure pondering, with his hand to
his mouth. Therefore, the shoulder insignia were changed and in Cleveland we
discussed with Miss Reed and General Ireland how much change might have to be
made to make this look like General Wood. Mrs. Ireland thought it already looked
considerably like him and so Cornwell let it go. The figure on the left, between
Finlay and Agramonte in the earlier version, didn't look like anybody but based on
General Truby's photograph in the detachment on the hospital stairs, the portrait
now is a pretty good resemblance of him and is supposed to indicate him. Which
one of the figures in the upper right corner on the porch railing is supposed to be
Dr. Cooke, I do not know. May I give you my frank opinion that Mr. Cornwell is not
a portrait painter. I have been rather amazed to find how difficult it seemed to
be for him to imagine how a person looked at one angle when he had photographs of
a man from another angle. Mr. Cornwell has the tendency to make the persons in
his portrait have rather bold, haggard features with high cheek bones, a thin face
and lines which I suppose are meant to lend character to the face.
It is the one in whats.

I just have the first colored proof of the painting. It is much better than
the pictures but even so General Truby's and your (General Kean) faces are not as
full as I believe they were. I imagine both the faces of Moran and Kissinger look
older than they should have been but all I could do was to call this to his atten-
tion and abide by the changes or lack of them which he made.

Now to the immediate necessity. The painting has already been reproduced in
one newspaper with certain erroneous identification marks. It is to be reproduced
in Hygeia and Kellogg was still in the mood not to identify at least three of the
figures. When I told him that history would demand more accuracy than that he has
now agreed to name these men and has suggested that I name them. I do not feel com-
petent to do so without at least your help. Which of the two men on the porch rail-
ing do you think looks most like Dr. Cooke? The other one remains unidentified. Do
you think that the mustachioed figure which was more or less copied from Jernegan's
portrait should be labeled in truth Jernegan (that is, the figure on the left of
Moran and Kissinger)? Which additional soldier volunteer should have his name assigned
to the man in the rear of the group on the right, that is, the man between Moran and
the Cuban volunteer--or should we merely state that he is another soldier volunteer?
Which if any of the Cuban volunteers deserves to have his name attached, or should
we merely call him “a Cuban volunteers”? Kellogg was in the mood to have the one
soldier volunteer in the rear represent Andrus for two reasons: (1) because he co-
operated with Kellogg and Cornwell and (2) because he, according to his own story,
took Reed's place and volunteered toward the end of the experiments when Reed in-
sisted on utilizing an infected mosquito which would not otherwise be utilized. I
personally am willing to let the Cuban and the additional soldier volunteer go un-
named. I think Jernegan should be named and that leaves still for us to name one
of the two figures on the railing. Please send me your suggestions and comments
at once as the key to all these figures must be published in Hygeia in their October
issue. It occurred to me that Dr. Carter might be put in or perhaps Dr. Roger Post
Ames should be the one.
as one drews the picture

I am delighted that you and General Truby are in it. Both of you have modestly
protested to me and signified your surprise that you are in but you both deserve
eminently to be in and you should not feel self-conscious about it. I am delighted,
General Kean, to have you send me the extract from the Annual Report of the Secretary
of War, 1902. I did not need this to feel strongly that you should be in the painting
General Kean - 3 - August 19, 1941
but I am most interested to have it.

I am sending a carbon copy of this to General Truby. I will write to Mr.
Kellogg as soon as I hear from you and tell him of the erroneous title which the
New York Mirror gave you.

You will remember that I sent you the enclosed picture given me by Senora
Rodriguez-Leon (Miss Agramonte). Dr. Albertini has recently identified the figures
as follows: from left to right, seated, Drs. Carlos J. Finlay and Juan Guiteras;
standing, Drs. Alfredo Dominguez Roldan, Aristides Agramonte, Taylor, Antonio
Diaz Albertini, and American visitor whose name he was not aware of, and Dr. Hugo
Roberts, presently Chief of the Quarantine Department of Cuba. Can you concur
in this identification? Please return the portrait to me.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P S Hench P. S. Hench, M. D.
